Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story: I stared at my phone, the sales dashboard glowing with numbers that made my manager proud. It was only Wednesday, and I was already on track to smash my weekly quota. The thrill of success buzzed in my chest, but it was quickly overshadowed by the reminder vibrating in my pocket: today was the start of Navaratri, and my family was waiting for me at the temple, hours away. As a Hindu, I was expected to be present, to chant, to offer flowers, to fast, and to immerse myself in the rituals that connected me to my ancestors and my faith. But as a telemarketer, I was expected to keep calling, to keep selling, to keep the numbers climbing. My manager’s words echoed in my mind—“Don’t lose momentum!”—while my mother’s gentle voice reminded me, “This festival comes once a year, beta.” My heart pounded as I weighed the headset in my hand, torn between the ringing phones and the distant sound of temple bells, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
